Justification: To assess for any visible abnormalities, such as asymmetry, deformities, or signs of distress.
To identify any areas of tenderness, crepitus, or abnormal masses.
To evaluate for any abnormal heart sounds, murmurs, or signs of ischemia.
To check for any abnormal lung sounds, such as wheezing or crackles, which may indicate respiratory issues.
To evaluate circulation and check for any signs of peripheral vascular disease.

Physical Exam: Blood pressure measurement in both arms
Justification: To assess for any significant differences that may indicate vascular issues.
To rule out any abdominal causes of chest pain, such as referred pain from gastrointestinal issues.
To evaluate for signs of heart failure or fluid overload.

Physical Exam: Neurological examination of the upper extremities
Justification: To assess for any neurological deficits that may indicate a more serious condition.
To check for diaphoresis or any signs of cyanosis that may indicate distress or poor perfusion.
